data.title: HDTV - getting computer 1080i/720p output into ATSC format?
data.meta_description: NOTE: NTSC = Standard Definition regular old color broadcasts.ATSC = MPEG-2 data, wrapped in error-correction, modulated using 8VSB. The "over-the-air"...
data.text:
NOTE:
NTSC = Standard Definition regular old color broadcasts.
ATSC = MPEG-2 data, wrapped in error-correction, modulated using 8VSB. The "over-the-air" standard for HDTV and what TVs with "HDTV Tuners" are capable of receiving and decoding.
Component = Analog HDTV signal that is NOT RELATED to ATSC at all; this is different than NTSC where the broadcast and "local" composite signals were the same


Let us suppose that I have an analog video signal that is NTSC. It may be broadcast on a channel (say channel 6) or it may be composite/S-video. It is coming from a video production area and for our purposes it is a black-box that we can't modify or control in any way... might as well be the local news.

Also let us say that I have a bunch of large LCD-TVs or Plasmas (40-46in range); they are widescreen 16:9. They have both analog NTSC tuners as well as ATSC digital tuners. Obviously if we just pipe the 4:3 signal to them we either get black bars on the sides or everyone looks really fat. Neither is an acceptable solution.

I want to display the 4:3 NTSC signal on the left of the widescreens but use a PC to "overlay" graphics, clock, weather, whatever on the right-side so there aren't any black bars; basically fill in the blank area with useful information. It will also look really cool.


In the old SD world I can do something like this easy... I just slap an ATI All-in-Wonder in the PC and use the Windows API to grab the input video to display it, overlay the graphics, and the All-in-Wonder does a fine job of spitting it out. I can hook that output to an NTSC modulator (which can be picked up for cheap) and distribute it all over the building and various TVs can tune to it.

If there were just one Widescreen TV to do this on it would be easy as pie even on a widescreen HDTV: I would just use the Component YPbPr output and go direct into the LCD-TV, then set the videocard to an HDTV-compatible resolution.

Alas, that will not do as this needs to be fed to (potentially) a hundred LCD-TVs of varying sizes throughout the building.


With me so far? I'm going to go on a small rabit trail...

In the current NTSC world, since the broadcast and local signals are the same a modulator is a fairly simple analog device that just takes the local audio/video and slaps it into a given "channel" in the VHF/UHF range. By tying the cables of various modulators together (or using a combiner) you end up with several channels of video data on one coax cable. This is similar (but much less complicated and expensive) to what the cable company does.

You then run the output of this combined signal into a big amplifier that has coax inputs and outputs and now you have a powerful signal that can be run through various splitters all over the building so 100+ TVs can watch any of the available channels in decent clarity.



Now back to the problem at hand... since (in the HDTV world) the broadcast and local formats are completely different (analog 1080i/720p vs digital MPEG2-8VSB modulated) I cannot just slap the output of an All-In-Wonder's Composite cables into an el-cheapo modulator. Something needs to perform the MPEG-2 encoding first. Then something needs to add the overhead data and do the 8VSB encoding to place the data onto a tunable channel.


(NOTE: DVB-ASI is a standard for placing one or more MPEG-2 streams onto the wire for moving them around video booths, tv stations, or whatever the case may be. I've never worked with it before myself.)

The closest thing I've found so far is this device that takes DVB-ASI data and generates an ATSC broadcast signal. I can certainly take the output of this device and plug it into the combiner and be broadcasting on an HDTV channel. The analog and HDTV channels can even co-exist on the same wire which is handy.


The problem is I have absolutely no clue how to generate the DVB-ASI signal from the PC (besides I have a feeling that the KTech box linked above costs an arm and a leg anyway).


An ideal solution would be a videocard that had an ATSC HDTV output mode on it; the card would take the frame-buffer, perform a real-time MPEG2 encoding, then do the 8VSB modulation and give an ATSC modulated output that can be tuned on any HDTV tuner. That might be asking a bit much but it would certainly solve my problem.



The reason I'm forced into HDTV is because I'm not aware of any way to transmit widescreen information on a regular NTSC channel.

I can't re-run cabling in the building and it wouldn't do me any good anyway because we need around 6 channels and the LCD-TVs must be able to tune into a given channel. That's why a closed-circuit TV distribution system was run and installed in the first place.



So I know this might be a bit in-depth for this forum but any suggestions or pointers would certainly be appreciated. I'm obviously trying to do this for minimal cost.
